IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
On Wednesday, June 07, 2023, at approximately 0720 hours, Detective Navarro #2152 of the Prince George’s County Police Narcotics Enforcement Division was conducting proactive drug trafficking interdiction efforts at the United Parcel Service Burtonsville Facility located at 14841 Sweitzer Lane, Laurel, Prince George’s County, Maryland 20707.
During these efforts, Detective Navarro observed a brown cardboard box that displayed
numerous indicators that it contained controlled dangerous substances (CDS) and it was removed from the delivery stream for further investigation. 
 
The shipment displayed the following information (written below as written on the label):
1Z 5XR 373 01 0655 0071. [This tracking number is a unique tracking number assigned only to
this parcel.]
FROM:
SUGARLAND
6264478260
411 E HUNTINGTON DR SUITE 107
ARCADIA CA 91006

SHIP TO:
ANTHONY CHARLES LANGFORD
5623 MILLWHEEL PL
COLUMBIA MD 21045-2563
Detective Navarro noted that the shipment was in a brown cardboard box and displayed characteristics of a drug laden parcel. Further, by querying the United Parcel Service tracking number, your affiant discovered that the parcel was sent from California, Arcadia; a city and state known to Detective Navarro to be a possible source state for controlled dangerous substances. 
 
Based on a totality of the circumstances, Detective Navarro, along with his canine partner “Molly” conducted a canine drug scan on the parcel with tracking number 1Z 5XR 373 01 0655 0071. The drug scan was conducted on the target parcel along with other non-targeted parcels. Detective Navarro’s canine partner “Molly” gave an alert followed by an indication for the odor of controlled dangerous substances on the target parcel bearing United Parcel Service tracking number 1Z 5XR 373 01 0655 0071 by passive response of sitting and staring.
 
Drug detector canine “Molly” is trained to detect the odor of controlled dangerous substances. These substances include marijuana, cocaine, heroin, ecstasy and methamphetamine. Upon detection of the odor of any of these (six) controlled dangerous substances, the canine’s behavior will change. The canine is trained to come to a final response of sitting and or starring at the source of the odor. This is called a “passive” final response. This response may also indicate items recently contaminated with, or associated with, the odor of one or more of the controlled dangerous substances.
 
Detective Navarro and “Molly” have completed a 400-hour drug detection canine course with the Prince George’s County Police Department and “Molly” is certified in the detection of the odors of Marijuana, Cocaine, Heroin, Methamphetamine and Ecstasy through the North American Police Working Dog Association. Additionally, the Prince George’s County Police Department also requires all canine handlers to complete to a minimum of 8 hours of maintenance training per month.
 
After this canine drug scan, Detective Navarro seized this parcel bearing tracking number 1Z 5XR 373 01 0655 0071 from the aforementioned United Parcel Service facility in Prince George’s County, Maryland. He then contacted investigators at the Metropolitan Area Drug Task Force and this writer, Trooper First Class Moreno #5652, also assigned to the Metropolitan Area Drug Task Force. Your affiant recovered the parcel at approximately 0855 hours and secured it at the MADTF office located at CED Headquarters Howard County, Maryland where it was stored for safe keeping.

A search and seizure warrant was authored and granted, by the honorable judge Powell.

Upon execution of the search warrant revealed a cardboard tubing with eleven heat sealed baggies of Marijuana inside, with an approximate weight of 6100 grams.  

At approximately 1400 hours, investigators conducted surveillance at the target home address and made contact with Anthony Charles Langford, with a DOB of 6/22/2010 who was listed as one of the tenants that resided at the residence. A discussion with Mr. Langford resulted in negative results, as he advised us that he smokes marijuana, but was not expecting a parcel or anyone that was expecting a shipment.

Secondary processing of the above listed evidence was conducted and the evidence was packaged and sealed under Maryland State Property # P344587 and weight, including all packaging at 8700 grams, verified by Cpl. Deibel. The parcel of marijuana was stored in the Maryland state Police CED Headquarters’ Evidence Locker and was seized for destruction.
 Members of the MADTF will continue to monitor this address for any further shipments and conduct follow ups accordingly.

All events did occur in Howard County, Maryland.

Case suspended.
